Hays came in from his camp some 10 miles off.  Anxiously awaiting news from the seat of Govt. has  40 men under arms - has orders to be near San Antonio & on the lookout.  
There are Mexican troops 'Contadores' who look out after smugglers & with them Hays has a skirmish to send them off.  Hays does not think it would be judicious to commence surveying for us at this moment but will accompany us thro the greater part of the colony & having pointed  out, will survey during the summer.  for some days past public prayers have been offered up for rain

The Mexican To?n found was returning to Rio Grande - We cross-questioned him - It appears that the party we took for 'Corlados' had robbed our prisoner?  who lives now in San Fernando - had been robbed of 3 Horses &c Huston pursued with his father & 2 other friends, they left here at the Nueces & he went on to San Anto - stopped there -? & is returning to San Fernando with a letter (dated 31 May) with some coffee etc as a present.   We have not held a council of war upon him yet - He gives a pretty good account of himself -

Comanches.  About a month over 300 Comanches & their families came into Presidio to trade 3 or 400 Horses & Mules & have gone down between the Rio Grande & Nueces Mustang hunting.  

The principal chief is named G samonica & the chief interpreter Santana.  Woll has its ?nders? not to make war upon them - they rob from Mexican in the ? & sell on lower part of river - game has been scarce in their country & they Eat Mustangs - Presidio 2 Lgs from River -  from here to Rio Grande 66 miles -
 This river (La Leona) appears from all accounts to be one of the Garden of Eden of Texas - The river neither increasing or decreasing much & irrigation can be suredly carried on -

Removed for the night 1 Mile higher up for pastures - all about here found Comanche Camps prob: if  last year when they returned from the coast - The banks of the Frio are generally steep & deep - Irrigation could not be profitably  resorted to, but theres an Valley Canadas

hole - passed some - good pastures   The Comanches it is supposed have eaten 20,000 mustangs during the last    5 years -  They Barbecue mustangs sometimes, which by digging a large hole in the ground  putting stones in making them hot then in goes the Mustang, other stones laid on & then a big fire sometimes as a tit-bit the head.   Pringle Camp - crosses the Creek zig-zag down - but in a straight line 5 or 6 miles S.E. pastures good - Water only in holes in Ck - passed all sorts of trails.

Went down W side of Elm ck 8 or 10 miles where it enters the Rio Frio - at the juncture are met groves of Elms in particular, Live Oak - It may be seen in going towards the Frio^ & Elm that when considerable freshets exist they cover large tracks of land forming generally large sloughs (which sloughs make a bed & then enter the River again) by descending one gets to the prairie. This river with some other streams in Texas have the property like that of Avernns in Sicily - of losing itself & then some 25 miles below rising again.  (Examine this subject).  Some 80 or 90 by rd up Nueces down Presidio Crossing is an old Spanish Mission & it is supposed mines were worked about here - There is no Lake at the head of Nueces, but there is one spring.  Mountainous regions on the Nueces & other waters in vicinity rocky & bad - the vallies only good - 30 m from head of Nueces to the Las Moras Mts - Left Camp Plumpter.  went down the slough & soon got out of the land that overflows - Mustangs

Land bluffy & near river - too hot for red bugs or ticks - White Heron, Hawks, smaller birds - Some new flowers - wolves - deer - Turtles - Quails    Camped on road on E side of Bayou & Camp Bollaert -

It is said that if one seats himself quietly & away from others & no speaking that for even an hour the mosquito rushes heedlessly by - but should they hear a noise or see a movement, then commences their gyrating & stinging.  In honor of the above I call this Camp crossed out:  Pandemonium ?ritchew? .    The grant only embraces the E. bank of the Nueces, but if the Govt would not allow Some parts of the opposite bank to be ?mel?ded - Land ? or head rights could be purchased & rented where required -  Bottom land red light colour - away from it on the undulating prairies & Lomas, land Harsh & ?vered

Saturday 15th
Last night - after 2 unclear words - The gnats & small flies nearly blinded us - the effluvia from the Slough nearly choked us  Frogs ( Brils? ) crickets & such like small fry commenced their whine - Monious? notes - no breeze & very sultry.  No sooner had we had Supper & bethought to seek upon upon [sic] our pallets, with the idea that a few snakes, scorpions, centipedes & lizards - independent of wolves panthers & such like, when Myriads upon Myriads of gulley-nipper Mosquitos commenced their discordant buzzing & stinging - which was kept up until Morning.  No one slept altho' Much fatigued.  We moved about sullenly from one place to

Morning fine & cool - For the last 2 or 3 days country more open & 2 unclear words but away from river want of water. altho there are Sloughs which are inland 8 to 10 miles, then when it  Turns from ? & when the river is high are filled with fresh water.  In the rainy season the whole of the country ? this river  has the reputation of being boggy. 

  The best  travelling is on the other side of the river & Tom says it is 80 miles from the junction of the Frio & Nueces to Sn Patricio.
  6 miles S.E came to some back water - 2 Miles more S.E. struck river at the first open spot we have seen.  the river

They have been known to bite persons severely when bathing.   Few Cat-fish - streams thick & running 4 miles.  Went fishing lost 3 hooks - owing to branches of trees under water - banks petty precipitous & dense vegetation    5 miles E. 5 do S.S.E.   Deer of Texas peculiar to it - the young kid or fawn Spotted like our fallow deer
  Tom Hancock - at 8 years of age when going to  see his Mother who had a stock farm far in Illinois was made prisoner by the Winnebagos that had killed his brother just before & some other white people.  Tom remained in captivity 18 months with 2 white girls   he was treated pretty well, & did not get as much whipping as the other indian boys.  Hunting, fishing & shooting frogs was his great delight - The Indians have prophets & stated times

4 miles on rd came to an old corral - pretty country - groves of Meskit & Live & Post oak More to Corpus Christi X  Found many old friends Clay Dawes, Stevensen? Kinney &c - Kindly recd - We have been traveling between Scylla & Charybon? - on 27th May this place was rented [sic: raided?] by 25 Lipans X to that Horses &c wounding Col Cooke thro' the eye - there were only 8 men at the 'Rancho' on 30 ulto - The Lipans* ( X wishing to pass off as Comanches) some say they were Comanches re- appeared & drove off cattle & Horses - 30 went in pursuit 10 came up & re-captured horses, kill 5 indians - Indians parted then came a desperate fight - 3 of our party killed 5 wounded

Lipans = Apaches

taken by the Comanches whilst out burning - they brought him to San Antonio - Went in Sa Fé expedition made prisoner; taken to Mexico & worked in that city until released in June 1842 - was taken by Gl Woll & worked in chains - made two ineffectual Escapes - got a bad Mexican consumption fever - was liberated last Spring - but says now that he is 'used up' & is only 23.  he is small, delicately made, dried up - but has the eye of a hawk.  Poor Tom.  I am afraid thy days are numbered - quick? modest, intelligent & when he can be brought out - his conversation truthful & interesting

 The Lipan have gone towards San Anto - Hays has had a brush with the Comanches.  Mexico has refused to enter into any treaty about Texas -

Tuesday 25
This place Corpus Christi - 3 Leagues of it was purchased from a Mexican 1839 - by Col. Kinney who commenced trading with the Mexican frontier or rather supplying traders (smugglers) from there.  Continual have been the vicisitudes of this place, from both Mexicans & Indians, even up to the present moment.  At present there are some 30 to 40 fighting men - a few cannon & Gl Kinneys house fortified.

Wednesday 26

Even now when the Nueces has a deep stream the pass has only 2 ft water, & at times quite dry particularly after Northers - Col K. thinks it would not be difficult to widen the channel, but even then the mouth is very extended. Good Fandango & supper at 'Uncle Bob's", News arrived late at night of 2 more fights about 10 days some 40 miles from S. Anto on the Pintas believe a party of Comanches^ 70 or 80 warriors & Hays & his men - he had one killed SW - The Enemy 20 or 30 K - & many wounded  The chief seeing Hays asked hm to come & have a talk  H went out when the Indian tried to spear him  H Shot him.

Monday July 1.
Day light got under weigh & about 8 am got over Bar in 8 & 8 1/2  feet (high tide) bar at low water 6 feet
This is not an easy entrance - it is changeable.  Cheyne a pilot lives inside the pass on S W ends of St. Josephs Island - Shoals of Red Fish & other larger passing Skip - Jacks Mullet & other smaller, these in their flight take to shall water & are pestered by Myriads of Pelicans & Man o War birds, who ? their flight easily catch them - Large shoals of shells & when covered with sand form island.  Bay change annually - particularly after heavy rains & storms - 5 Min off P. Caballo
Tuesday 2
Day light off the Brazos - and then to Galveston - regularly worn out & nearly dead

Thursday 27
From parties who are coming in - they report much Indian sign all about.  At Kenneys fort & other spots looking well to their arms - Hays came accidentally upon his Comanches & the ? of one of his men alone Peter Fryer a frenchman Killed him
Friday 28
Afternoon left C.Christi - weather threatening & wind ahead - made little of it, - had to come to anchor - blew & gale & rain all night - we got all wet -
Saturday 29
At day break - found we were  only a few miles from C. C.  bore up for it, to dry our clothes etc. Noon left & at Sun Down came along side the 'Alert' tale 'Santana' made Aransas Pass & opposite the houses lost my blanket over bd - high water islands & reefs made up of shells.
Sunday 30
12 Miles to McGlovers Bluffs - 13 to the inside of pass - 25 miles, & 5 miles to the Bar.  Took in Beef & Vegetables

element_texts.text:
page reproduced upside down
By bright Leona's steepy banks

 We island rovers ride

Where crystal streams oe'r beds of rock

 In circling eddies glide.

O'er hill and dale & prairie broad

 Our Westward course we hold

Where roams in fearless liberty

 The Indian Warrior bold

And tho' Each tree may hide a foe

 And the red-man track our path

In mirthful mood we onward roe crossed out:  (go)

 And mock their savage wrath.

Dr George Cupples
In ages past these woods have heard

 But the Indian's savage yell

The panther's roar, the bear's fierce growl

 Or the wild deer's plaintive bell -

Dr. C
